sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This chapter describes each artifact that can be created within &argouml;. The chapter covers top-level general artifacts. The following chapters (see through ) cover each of the &argouml; diagrams.

There is a close relationship between this material and the properties tab of the details pane (see ). That section covers properties in general, in this chapter they are linked to specific artifacts.

sect1.title: The Model
sect1.para: The model is the top level artifact within &argouml;. In the UML meta-model it is a sub-class of package. In many respects within &argouml; it behaves similarly to a package (see ).

note.para: &argouml; is restricted to one model within the tool.

caution.para: In principle you can add a model to a class diagram using the context sensitive (&button2;) pop up menu Add To Diagramfrom the navigation pane. However this is very demanding of memory and may cause a problem with &argouml; running out of memory.

sect1.para: Where standard data types, classes and packages are loaded (the default, see ), these are sub-packages of the model.

note.para: In the current version of &argouml; these sub-packages are not initially visible from the model property pane as owned packages. However if you use the data type navigator from a suitable pane, you can navigate up to the model, and thereafter that data type's sub-packages will appear.

sect1.title: Datatype
sect1.para: Datatypes can be thought of as simple classes. They have no attributes, and any operations on them must have no side-effects. A useful analogy is primitive datatypes in a language like Java. The integer 3 stands on its own—it has no inner structure. There are operations (for example addition) on the integers, but when I perform 3 + 4 the result is a new number, 3 and 4 are unchanged by the exercise.

Within UML 1.3, DataType is a sub-class of the Classifier metaclass. It embraces the predefined primitive types (byte, char, double, float, int, long and short), the predefined enumeration, boolean and user defined enumeration types.

note.para: void is implemented as a class rather than a datatype within &argouml;

sect1.para: Within &argouml; new datatypes may be created using the New datatype button on the property tabs of the model and packages (in which case the new datatype is restricted in scope to the package), as well as the properties tab for datatype..
You can navigate to existing property types via the NavClass button on any property sheet that has a Type drop-down (for example attribute or parameter).

caution.para: UML 1.3 allows user defined datatypes to be placed on class diagrams. This is not permitted in &argouml;.

sect1.title: Stereotypes
sect1.para: Stereotypes are the main extension mechanism of UML, providing a way to derive specializations of the standard metaclasses. Stereotype is a sub-class of GeneralizableElement in the UML metamodel. Stereotypes are supplemented by constraints and tagged values.

New stereotypes are added from the model property tab (see , the package property tab (see ) or the stereotype property tab itself (see below). Properties of existing stereotypes can be reached by selecting the property tab for any artifact with that stereotype and using the navstereo button ( ) within the property tab.

note.para: Due to a bug in &argouml; newly created stereotypes do not appear in stereotype drop down menus. Where the stereotypes apply to a class, it is sufficient to select a new class and then select the original class back. However this does not work for other artifacts. The solution is to save and reload the model.

sect1.title: &argouml; Diagrams
sect1.para: &argouml; supports all eight primary types of diagrams defined by UML 1.3: i) use case; ii) class; iii) sequence; iv) state; v) collaboration; vi) activity; vii) component and viii) deployment. They are created using the Create Diagram drop down menu (see ).

note.para: &argouml; uses its deployment diagram to create both UML 1.3 component and deployment diagrams.

caution.para: State and activity diagrams are associated with a particular class, and can only be created when a class has been selected. In the current version of &argouml; they are not grayed out even when a class is not selected. However under these circumstances they will have no effect.

warning.para: There is currently no support for the UML 1.3 object diagram as a variant of the class diagram. It is possible to create simple object diagrams within the &argouml; deployment diagram.
